choices.text: Her risk of a thromboembolism is only elevated if she tests positive for antiphospholipid antibodies, which is only seen in 10% of lupus patients.
Her risk of a thromboembolism is only elevated if she tests positive for antiphospholipid antibodies, which is seen in about one-third of lupus patients.
Having SLE even without antiphospholipid antibodies is a significant risk factor for developing a blood clot
The longer one has had SLE, the higher the risk for a thromboembolism.

questions.text: A 37-year-old woman with a SLE presents for a routine follow up visit. She is compliant with her medication regimen containing hydroxychloroquine. An old friend of hers from high school recently passed away from a sudden pulmonary embolism, and the situation made her worried. She asks if she is at risk for a blood clot. What should you tell her?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Having SLE even without antiphospholipid antibodies is a significant risk factor for developing a blood clot

 

While testing positive for antiphospholipid antibodies puts a patient at a particularly high risk for developing a thromboembolism, even SLE patients without antiphospholipid antibodies are at an increased risk of developing a blood clot. Acquired protein S deficiency and inflammation, in general, are thought to play a role in the pathophysiology. Anywhere from 10 to 26% of lupus patients will develop a blood clot.

 

Incorrect Answers:

A. Simply having lupus, regardless of the presence of antiphospholipid antibodies, is a risk factor for developing a blood clot. Approximately one-third of patients with SLE will test positive for antiphospholipid antibodies.

 

B. Although it is true that one-third of lupus patients will test positive for antiphospholipid antibodies, the other two-thirds are still at an increased risk for developing a blood clot.

 

D. One study showed that a lupus patient’s risk for developing a blood clot is highest immediately after diagnosis, another study showed that the risk remains elevated for the remainder of the disease course. Regardless, it is not thought that the risk for a blood clot increases with time after the diagnosis.

choices.text: Inhibits osteoblast production and differentiation
Uncouples bone remodeling and shortens bone remodeling cycle
Release of tumor necrosis factor a and interleukins IL-1 and IL-6

questions.text: By which of the following mechanisms can hyperthyroidism and thyrotoxicosis increase the risk of osteoporosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Uncouples bone remodeling and shortens bone remodeling cycle

 

Hyperthyroidism causes osteoporosis by uncoupling bone remodeling and by shortening the bone remodeling cycle.

 

Incorrect Answers:

 

A. This is a mechanism responsible for increased risk of osteoporosis due to glucocorticoids.

 

C. This is the mechanism of inflamation.

 

D. This is one of the mechanisms by which menopause results in increased bone resorption and loss.

questions.text: A 37-year-old software engineer presents to the clinic with concerns about his "overwhelming sexual urges." He describes an insatiable need for sexual gratification, leading him to masturbate multiple times a day, even during short breaks at work. This has led to embarrassing situations, including nearly being caught by a colleague. He also admits to frequenting explicit websites daily, often in inappropriate settings. Despite feeling guilty and trying to control these urges, he feels powerless over them. He's been married for 10 years, and though he's intimate with his wife almost daily, he still can't curb his urges. Considering his distress and impairment in daily functioning, which of the following medications would be the most appropriate initial treatment?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. SSRIs

 

The patient's presentation is indicative of compulsive sexual behaviour (CSB), previously known as "sexual addiction." CSB is typified by persistent and powerful sexually arousing fantasies, urges, or actions that are distressing or disruptive.

    •  
  • SSRIs (b): The involvement of serotonergic systems in CSB has made selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors an effective initial treatment option. Clinical trials have shown SSRIs to reduce the frequency and intensity of CSB-related fantasies and actions.
  • Benzodiazepines (a): While effective for anxiety and acute agitation, benzodiazepines are not the primary treatment for CSB and can cause dependence.
  • Antipsychotics (c): These are mainly used for psychotic disorders and are not the first-line treatment for CSB.
  • Mood stabilizers (d): Although used for bipolar disorder and certain impulse control disorders, they are not the primary treatment for CSB.

questions.text: A 5-year-old male child presents to the pediatric clinic with complaints of recurrent headaches, vomiting. Parents report that the headaches have been progressively worsening over the past few weeks, and the vomiting episodes are occurring almost daily. They are also concerned about the child's developmental delay, noting a significant loss of previously acquired skills such as speaking in full sentences and walking steadily. On physical examination, the child's head circumference is noted to be above the 97th percentile for his age, with a tense and bulging anterior fontanelle. The child exhibits the "sunsetting" sign, where the sclera is visible above the irises when looking downward. Additionally, he has an unsteady gait and difficulty walking without support. MRI is shown here. What is the likely cause of hydrocephalus?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Tectal glioma

 

MRI is showing an isointense lesion at the tectum with associated dilation of the ventricles, consistent with hydrocephalus as described by the clinical scenario.

choices.text: Mouse ear sign on X-ray
Involvement of only the proximal interphalangeal joints of a digit

questions.text: Which of the following findings suggest a diagnosis of psoriatic arthritis in a patient with psoriasis, dactylitis, and tenderness in the sacroiliac joints?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Mouse ear sign on X-ray

 

Psoriatic arthritis is a seronegative spondylarthropathy that predominantly affects the DIP joints in the hand and feet. One or more joints are affected and will be warm, tender, and erythematous. Asymmetrical oligoarthritis is the most common presentation. The radiological signs associated with psoriatic arthritis include bilateral asymmetrical disease with involvement of distal interphalangeal joints, enthesitis, bone proliferation, and preserved bone density. The “mouse ear” sign refers to erosions with new bone formation, which consists of fluffy periostitis. The “ray sign” is another characteristic finding that refers to involvement of all joints in one digit. Dactylitis results in sausage digits. Skin lesions usually precede arthritis.

 

Incorrect Answers:

 

A. Rheumatoid factor is negative in the seronegative sponylarthropathies.

 

C. Symmetric disease occurs in only 15% of patients.

 

D. Involvement of the distal interphalangeal joints is characteristic.

choices.text: Men with suspected urethral stricture
Urine incontinence in pediatric population

questions.text: This device shown in the image is used in:
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Men with suspected urethral stricture

 

The given device is used for measuring urine flow rate in men with suspected bladder outlet obstruction (BOO).

 

In women to measure urine flow rate, the device shown is as below.

 

 

  • Men with lower urinary tract symptoms (LUTS) and women with recurrent UTIs or LUTS are frequently investigated with a flow rate and a USG residual urine at the first clinic appointment.
  • A peak flow rate (Qmax) in excess of 15  mL/s suggests that significant BOO is not present, whereas a flow rate of <10 mL/s suggests that BOO is present.
  • A very low flow rate with a very protracted pattern of voiding is suggestive of a urethral stricture

choices.text: Repeat examination on a later date with pre-treatment with ibuprofen

questions.text: What is the next step in management of a 32-year-old woman with a 5-year history of primary infertility with bilateral tubal block seen at cornua on hysterosalpingogram?
questions.solution: Ans. D. Repeat examination on a later date with pre-treatment with ibuprofen

questions.text: When performing flexor tendon repair, which of the following pulleys must be preserved?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. A2 and A4

 

Any exposure of the flexor tendons in their sheath and pulley system runs the risk of disrupting a magnificent engineering wonder. The pulleys serve a very important function in creating strong lever arms for the tendons. The most important of these are the A2 and A4 pulleys. Transection results in 'bowstringing' with subsequent weakness of flexion.

questions.text: A patient is diagnosed with moderate psoriatic arthritis resistant to NSAIDs. Which of the following is recommended as first line therapy to prevent joint destruction?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Infliximab

 

Psoriatic arthritis is a seronegative spondylarthritis characterized by asymmetric oligoarthritis or symmetric polyarthritis. Skin changes typically precede arthritis. They include scaly silver plaques on the extensor surfaces of the forearm and lower extremity. Five to ten percent of patients with psoriasis are affected by psoriatic arthritis. The American College of Rheumatology/National Psoriasis Foundation currently recommend treatment with TNF-alpha inhibitors for treatment naive patients with active PSA. These guidelines recommend oral small molecules such as methotrexate if patients do not have severe PSA and either have contraindications to TNF-inhibitor therapy or are concerned about initiating treatment with a biologic as a first line therapy.

 

Incorrect Answers:

 

A. Methotrexate is an oral small molecule which can be used in treating PSA.

 

B. When glucocorticoids are used, they are applied topically or injected locally.

 

D. Mesalamine is the active metabolite of sulfasalazine. It is not used in treatment of psoriatic arthritis.

questions.text: A 34-year-old man presents with a 3-month history of knee pain, with an inability to squat. The most likely diagnosis is?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Posterior horn meniscal tear.

 

The most likely diagnosis here is a tear of the posterior horn of the medial meniscus. The key is the pain when squatting. Primary osteoarthritis is unlikely in a 34-year-old and the other options are possible but are more likely to present with less specific pain and often swelling.

choices.text: A polygenic disorder with progressive depigmentation.
An autosomal dominant disorder involving the C-kit protooncogene.
An autoimmune condition with progressive depigmentation.
A sporadic condition without a genetic link.

questions.text: A 32-year-old female presents to the dermatology clinic concerned about white patches on her skin that she noticed since childhood. Physical examination reveals depigmented patches with a symmetrical distribution, especially prominent on the ventral aspect of her body and mid-forehead. White forelock is noted as shown in the image below. She mentions that her grandfather had similar patches since his birth. She also reports that a cousin on her father's side has been recently diagnosed with rheumatoid arthritis. Given the patient's history and clinical presentation, which of the following describes the underlying cause of her condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. An autosomal dominant disorder involving the C-kit protooncogene.

 

The patient's presentation is characteristic of Piebaldism (Option B). Piebaldism is an autosomal dominant condition caused by mutations in the C-kit protooncogene, leading to the absence of melanocytes in certain areas of the skin and hair, resulting in depigmented patches and white hair strands within the patches. The stable nature of the patches, presence since childhood, and a positive family history are pointers to piebaldism.

 

Other options:

 

A) Vitiligo is a polygenic disorder with progressive depigmentation, but it often starts later in life (typically between ages 2 to 40 years) and does not usually have a stable pattern.

 

C) This option alludes to Vitiligo which is associated with other autoimmune conditions like thyroid disorders, rheumatoid arthritis, etc. But the clinical presentation, especially the stable patches with white hair strands and the age of onset, doesn't match vitiligo.

 

D) A sporadic condition without a genetic link does not fit the patient's presentation, especially considering the family history.

 

In summary, the symmetrical distribution of patches, presence since childhood, white hair strands within the patches, and positive family history make piebaldism the most likely diagnosis.

questions.text: An 84-year-old woman with a history of hypertension and spinal stenosis who was noted to have a sudden-onset tachycardia during preoperative evaluation. The patient received intravenous verapamil at which time she converted to normal sinus rhythm. Extended-release verapamil was continued without further dysrhythmia recurrence. What is the likely diagnosis based on the ECG shown below?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Ectopic Atrial Tachycardia

 

Small P waves are seen immediately preceding each QRS complex. The P-wave axis is negative in the limb leads suggesting an ectopic atrial focus. This is immediately followed by a short PR interval and a narrow QRS complex. This represents Supraventricular Tachycardia (red arrows) Diffuse Non-Specific ST-T Changes (blue arrows)are present.

 

Most likely, this represents an ectopic atrial tachycardia originating low in the atrium in close proximity to the atrioventricular node. This would explain the negatively oriented P-wave axis and short PR interval as intra-atrial transit time to the atrioventricular node is shorter based on the abnormal origin of the atrial tachycardia focus.

choices.text: Black body with grey shoulder
Grey body with black and white shoulder
Black body with white shoulder
Grey body with black shoulder

questions.text: In a romantic Bollywood scene, Alia Bhatt finds herself utterly captivated and literally blown away by Ranbir Kapoor's striking good looks. Overcome by his charm, she finds herself breathless and in need of some assistance to catch her breath. Swiftly, a medical oxygen cylinder is brought to her aid, ensuring she can continue the scene in good health. What is color of medical oxygen cylinder?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Black body with white shoulder

 

Anesthetic Equipment

questions.text: A patient is treated with cisplatin and bleomycin and develops renal failure. Which of the following is a characteristic of renal failure that may occur specifically when cisplatin is given with bleomycin?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Thrombotic microangiopathy

 

When cisplatin is administered with bleomycin, it may be associated with thrombotic microangiopathy with features of the hemolytic-uremic syndrome or thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura, presumably reflecting direct vascular injury and secondary platelet activation. This has also been reported with gemcitabine and cisplatin combination therapy.

 

Cisplatin-associated renal tubular dysfunction and cumulative renal impairment can limit the dose of cisplatin. Multiple mechanisms contribute to renal dysfunction as a result of cisplatin toxicity, including tubular epithelial cell toxicity, vasoconstriction in the renal microvasculature, and pro-inflammatory effects. The proximal tubules are selectively injured by cisplatin. The nephrotoxicity of cisplatin is possibly the result of enhanced renal uptake of cisplatin by organic transporters, followed by reduced expression and function of sodium-dependent glucose and amino-acid transporters, reduced expression and function of magnesium and water transporters, metabolism of cisplatin to glutathione and conjugates of cysteinyl-glycine, and generation of reactive oxygen species.

 

Renal impairment varies in incidence depending on up the dose and frequency of drug administration but has been seen in more than 50% of cases in some trials. Incidence and severity increase with subsequent courses and can become irreversible over time, so the progression of renal impairment is an indication for discontinuation of therapy. Higher doses for bone marrow transplantation cannot be used due to severe toxicity, so carboplatin, which is a less toxic analog, may be used in that setting. In most cases, urine output in patients with nephrotoxicity remains above 1000 mL per day unless the renal failure is advanced. This is due to the induction of a concentrating defect, possibly as a result of platinum-induced damage to the loop of Henle. Hypomagnesemia occurs in over 50% of cases of cisplatin-induced nephrotoxicity due to urinary magnesium wasting. Resultant hypomagnesemia may exacerbate toxicity of cisplatin. Fanconi-like syndrome accompanies cisplatin-mediated nephrotoxicity, although classic Fanconi syndrome has not been reported. Renal salt wasting is a rare manifestation of cisplatin nephrotoxicity that has been described in some small series and cases.

questions.text: A 6-year-old child presents with a history of recurrent episodes of joint pain, swelling, and rash. The rash appears as erythematous, scaly plaques over the cheeks and buttocks. The child's parents mention that these symptoms seem to flare up periodically and are associated with fever. Physical examination reveals synovitis in multiple joints, and eye examination shows uveitis. Genetic testing is performed, revealing a mutation in the NOD2 gene. Which of the following conditions is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Blau Syndrome

 

Blau syndrome is a rare autoinflammatory disorder characterized by recurrent episodes of arthritis, skin rash, and uveitis. The distinctive feature of Blau syndrome is the presence of granulomatous inflammation affecting the joints, skin, and eyes. Mutations in the NOD2 gene are associated with this condition. Options A, B, and D do not typically manifest with the triad of symptoms described in the case.

choices.text: Can be used with cervical injuries

questions.text: In the blockbuster Bollywood movie "Jawaan", Shahrukh Khan plays a daring anaesthesiologist. In a dramatic scene, he swiftly uses the device given in the picture below to secure the airway of a fellow spy who experiences respiratory distress during a high-stakes mission. This heroic medical intervention allows them to escape a precarious situation and proceed with their mission, showcasing medical knowledge in action on the big screen. Which of these is not an advantage of this device?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Prevents aspiration

 

 

  • Advantages: Lower incidence of score throat
    • Requires less anaesthetic dept than tracheal tube or supraglottic device.
    • No need of muscle relaxants
    • The face mask may be the most cost efficient method for short cases.
    • Laryngeal mask is used for maintenance of airway in patients in whom tracheal intubation is difficult or impossible.
    • It is a cuffed mask designed to fit closely over the laryngeal aperture. It forms a seal around the larynx.
    • Laryngeal mask airway is also called as Bane Mask (after the name of its invertor).
    • It provides relatively safe anaesthesia for adults and children in place of tracheal intubation.
    • It should be remembered that, it is only an adjunct to airway management but not a substitute for tracheal intubation, Moreover it does not protect the airway from pulmonary aspiration.

questions.text: When compared to the non-dominant side, which of the following shoulder motions is characteristically decreased in the throwing arm of athletes?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Internal rotation (IR)

 

Glenohumeral internal rotation deficit (GIRD) is associated with throwing athletes. Repetitive throwing (cocking phase and deceleration phase) leads to a tight posterior capsule and loose anterior capsule. It is associated with internal impingement. On examination the full arc of rotation at 90° is maintained but excessive ER is present at the expense of decreased IR (loss of >20° of IR at 90° compared to contralateral side), Treatment consists of posterior capsule stretching.

choices.text: Pain is intermittent, colicky and periumbilical
Fever is usually low grade and continuous
Anorexia is infrequently seen in children
Positive family history is seen in 1/3rd of patients

questions.text: Identify the incorrect statement about acute appendicitis:
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Anorexia is infrequently seen in children

  • In older age groups the classical features of acute appendicitis begin with poorly localised colicky abdominal pain. This is due to midgut visceral discomfort in response to appendiceal inflammation and obstruction. The pain is frequently first noticed in the periumbilical region and is similar to, but less intense than, the colic of small bowel obstruction.
  • Central abdominal pain is associated with anorexia, nausea and usually one or two episodes of vomiting that follow the onset of pain (Murphy).
  • Anorexia is a useful and constant clinical feature, particularly in children, who invariably also have vomiting.
  • The patient often gives a history of similar discomfort that settled spontaneously.
  • A family history is also useful as up to one-third of children with appendicitis have a first-degree relative with a similar

questions.text: Identify the incorrect pair:
questions.solution: Ans. D.  D - 4

questions.text: A patient with metastatic prostate cancer develops hypocalcemia during treatment with a bone antiresorptive agent. Which of the following agents is most likely to result in hypocalcemia?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Denosumab

 

Denosumab is a human monoclonal antibody that binds to the receptor activator of nuclear factor-KB ligand (RANKL), to inhibit osteoclastic resorption of bone. RANKL plays a key role in regulation of osteoclast formation, function, and survival.

 

Bone contributes to regulation of calcium and phosphate homeostasis, so inhibition of osteoclastic activity with an antiresorptive agent increases the risk of hypocalcemia. Denosumab is a more potent osteoclast inhibitor than bisphosphonate agents and hypocalcemia is more likely in patients who are treated this agent.

 

Calcium and vitamin D levels should be assessed before initiating therapy with any antiresorptive agent, with supplementation of low levels prior to initiation of treatment when indicated. Periodic monitoring is recommended during therapy. Compensatory mechanisms, including increased release of parathyroid hormone, contribute to maintenance of calcium and phosphorus homeostasis. In patients who have renal insufficiency or a disorder of mineral metabolism, levels should be checked within two weeks of initiation of therapy and more frequently thereafter.

 

Unless there is a contraindication, most patients should receive a total of 1000 mg of calcium (diet plus supplement) and 800 to 1200 IU of vitamin D daily during treatment with an antiresorptive agent.

 

Incorrect Answers:

A. Pamidronate is a bisphosphonate. Although it may result in hypocalcemia, hypophosphatemia, hypomagnesemia, and hypokalemia, denosumab is a more potent inhibitor of osteoclastic resorption of bone associated with a higher risk of hypocalcemia.

 

B. Zoledronic acid is a bisphosphonate and the risk of hypocalcemia and hypophosphatemia are lower with this agent compared to denusomab. Median time to initial occurrence of hypocalcemia for denusomab was also shorter, at 3.8 months compared to 6.5 months with zoledronic acid.

 

D. Ibandronate is a bisphosphonate derivative that has been infrequently associated with hypocalcemia in post-marketing studies and case reports.

questions.text: A patient presented with history of colicky abdominal pain and vomiting 5 years after a undergoing a Roux-en-Y gastric bypass for weight loss. Abdominal examination was unremarkable, barring some vague tenderness. CECT scan showed dilated small bowel loops. A decision to perform diagnostic laparotomy was made. Laparotomy revealed gangrenous small bowel about 4 feet in length. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Peterson’s space hernia

 

The given scenario of post operative intestinal obstruction following gastric bypass, with nonspecific CT findings is likely to be a strangulated internal hernia (Peterson’s space).

 

Internal hernias develop as weight is lost and hernia spaces open up after gastric bypass. CT scanning has a high rate of false negatives for internal hernia, so anyone presenting with severe, cramping abdominal pain 2–3 years after surgery needs to be high priority for investigation by laparoscopy. Closure of the internal hernia spaces is now standard of care in Roux-en-Y gastric bypass.

questions.text: A therapist observes distinct patterns in her sessions with a 35-year-old woman who has a turbulent history with relationships. Initially, the woman sings praises about the therapist, declaring her as the best thing that's happened to her. However, after a few sessions, she arrives agitated, accusing the therapist of not genuinely wanting to help her. These extreme shifts in perception occur frequently, creating a turbulent therapeutic environment. Which defense mechanism is predominantly being exhibited by this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Splitting

 

The patient is exhibiting "splitting," a defense mechanism where an individual fails to integrate the positive and negative qualities of oneself or others into cohesive images. People who employ splitting see things as either all good or all bad, making it hard for them to tolerate ambiguity. This is a common defense mechanism in borderline personality disorder.

  1. Reaction formation is when an individual behaves in a manner opposite to their feelings.
  2. Denial is the refusal to accept reality.
  3. Projection involves attributing one's own unacceptable feelings or impulses to someone else.

questions.text: In an action-packed medical drama, actress Nora Fatehi portrays a skilled neurologist performing a critical procedure. The scene intensifies as she meticulously performs a lumbar puncture on a patient to diagnose a mysterious condition. The audience is on the edge of their seats as Nora, maintaining her composure, feels a snap just before entering the epidural space, and successfully completes the procedure, adding a layer of medical intrigue to the movie. This is due to piercing of which structure?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Ligamentum flavum

 

Lumbar Puncture

 

Positioning

  • Patient is asked to lie in a lateral position, with thighs, knees, neck and back flexed in such a way that the knees touch the abdomen. This position widens the intervertebral space
  • Performed at or below the L3—L4 interspace which lies at the level of a line drawn between posterior superior iliac crests.
  • An alternative to lateral recumbent position is the seated position, with patient instructed to curl forward, trying to touch the nose to umbilicus.
  • Disadvantage of seated position: Measurement of opening pressure is not accurate.

 

Technique:

Proper local disinfection reduces the risk of introducing skin bacteria into subarachnoid space.

  • 3–5 mL of local anesthetic (1% lidocaine), is injected into subcutaneous tissue.
  • LP needle (usually 20–22 G) is inserted in midline, midway between two spinous processes & slowly advanced, with slight angulation directed upwards. Bevel of needle should be maintained in a horizontal position, parallel to direction of dural fibers & with flat portion of bevel pointed upward; this minimizes injury to fibers as dura is penetrated.
  • When LP is performed in sitting position, bevel should be maintained in vertical position.
  • In most adults, needle is advanced 4–5 cm before the subarachnoid space is reached; A sudden loss of resistance is felt when the ligamentumflavum is punctured.
  • If no fluid appears despite apparently correct needle placement, then the needle may be rotated 90°–180°. If there is still no fluid, stylet is reinserted & needle is advanced slightly.
  • Once the subarachnoid space is reached, a manometer is attached to needle & opening pressure measured.
  • Upper limit of normal opening pressure with the patient supine is 180 mm Hg in adults but may be as high as 200–250 mm Hg in obese adults.
  • CSF is allowed to drip into collection tubes; it should not be withdrawn with a syringe.
  • During lumbar puncture, the needle passes through the following anatomic structures before it enters the subarachnoid space:
    • Skin
    • Subcutaneous tissue
    • Supraspinous ligament
    • Interspinous ligament
    • Ligamentumflavum
    • Dura mater
    • Arachnoid mater

questions.text: A 19-year-old male student who recently attended a large university gathering is admitted to the emergency department. Over the past week, he developed a headache that was initially mild but progressively intensified. He also complains of fatigue, malaise, and muscle pain. He has a persistent cough, sore throat, and a high-grade fever for the past 4 days. On examination, his vital signs show a fever of 103°F and increased heart rate. Petechiae are noted spread over his extremities and trunk. Lumbar puncture shows increased white blood cells with a predominance of neutrophils. Gram stain reveals gram-negative diplococci. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Meningococcaemia

 

Meningococcemia (Option C) is the correct diagnosis. This condition is caused by Neisseria meningitidis, a gram-negative diplococcus. The patient's clinical presentation of high-grade fever, petechiae, and the finding of gram-negative diplococci on lumbar puncture strongly points towards a meningococcal infection. The recent attendance at a large gathering increases the risk as meningococcal infections can spread in crowded settings.

 

Other options:

 

A) Tuberculous meningitis is caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis. It often presents with a more insidious onset, and its hallmark is a chronic, subacute course with low-grade fever, weight loss, and night sweats. The lumbar puncture would show lymphocytic predominance with elevated protein.

 

B) Viral encephalitis may present with fever, headache, altered mental status, and even seizures. Lumbar puncture might show an elevated white blood cell count but usually with a lymphocytic predominance. Petechiae would not be a typical finding.

 

D) Lyme disease is caused by Borrelia burgdorferi, transmitted by tick bites. It is characterized by the erythema migrans rash, history of tick exposure, and joint pains. Neurological manifestations can occur but are usually seen in the later stages of the disease.

choices.text: Akinetic LV apex and mid-ventricular segments

questions.text: A 63-year-old previously healthy woman with no significant medical history develops an abnormal EKG following the repair of a closed femur fracture sustained in a high-speed motor vehicle crash. The procedure was notable for mild tachycardia and hypotension but was otherwise uncomplicated. ECG shows 1-2 mm ST elevations in leads V2-V4 and deep T-wave inversions in V5, V6, and aVL. Serum troponin is 0.8. The patient undergoes an emergent coronary angiography, which reveals no evidence of acute thrombus formation. Which of the following additional findings is likely present?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Akinetic LV apex and mid-ventricular segments

 

This patient demonstrates the classic presentation of stress-induced cardiomyopathy, also known as Takotsubo cardiomyopathy. This incompletely understood STEMI mimic typically follows severe emotional or physiological stress and may be due to an anatomic predisposition to ischemia in states of extreme catecholaminergic tone. The typical patient is a post-menopausal woman with ECG changes, including ST-elevations or pronounced T-wave inversions. Cardiac catheterization is required to make the diagnosis through an absence of significant coronary disease on angiography and akinesis of the LV apex (apical ballooning), typically overlapping a single vascular territory.

 

Incorrect Answers:

 

A. The diagnosis of Takotsubo is specifically in the absence of significant coronary lesions. Since this patient has no known risk factors, it is unlikely for her to have high-grade disease.

 

B. Ramus intermedius is a normal coronary anatomic variant involving a trifurcation of the left main coronary artery, with the ramus intermedius arising between the LAD and left circumflex. It is present in roughly 20% of individuals.

 

C. Severe MR would not typically cause any of these major findings.

questions.text: Following radical esophagectomy, patient develops breathlessness on post-operative day 5 (POD-5). Chest examination shows reduced air entry on left hemithorax. O2 supplementation is started, and patient is shifted for chest X ray. Chest x ray reveal moderate left sided pleural effusion. Intercostal drain is inserted, fluid is drained as shown. You will send this fluid for what assessment for confirming diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Chylomicrons

 

The given appearance of the fluid in the setting of esophagectomy, is suggestive of chylothorax due to thoracic duct injury.

 

During oesophagectomy, the thoracic duct and its tributaries may be damaged, postoperatively presenting as chylothorax.

 

The thoracic duct may also be injured during cervical lymphadenectomy, leading to a chylous leak from the neck wound after surgery.

 

Prolonged chylous drainage cannot be tolerated because there is loss not only of fluid and electrolytes but also important proteins as well as lymphocytes, which cannot be replaced

questions.text: According to European Society classification, an inguinal hernia of size 6 cm extending to the scrotum and deep ring occlusion test positive, with defect of size 3 cm is described as:
questions.solution:
Ans. D. PL2

 

Given scenario is a primary inguinal hernia, extending to bottom of scrotum with positive DROT (no swelling on occlusion of deep ring)- making it a likely indirect (lateral) hernia with defect of size 3 cm.

  • European Hernia Society classification of inguinal hernia:
  1. Primary or Recurrent (P/R)
  2. Lateral(indirect)/ Medial(direct)/ Femoral
  3. Finger breaths (1.5cm)- size of defect

 

Defect of 3 cm, primary, indirect hernia= PM2

questions.text: Which of the following mutations is associated with Crohn’s disease related primary small bowel adenocarcinoma?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. p53 mutations are associated with Crohn’s disease-associated small bowel adenocarcinoma.

 

Incorrect Answers:

 

D - C-kit mutations are characteristic of GIST tumors.

 

B and C. K-ras is associated with small bowel adenocarcinomas of the small bowel, while hMLH1 and hMSH2 are associated with Lynch-syndrome small bowel adenocarcinomas. The small bowel is often the first area to be affected by adenocarcinoma in up to 57% of patients with Lynch syndrome.

choices.text: Shorter transit times through the small bowel
Lower density of aerophilic gram-positive bacteria in the small bowel
Lower concentration of gram-negative bacteria in the small bowel
Higher concentration of microsomal enzymes in small bowel epithelia

questions.text: Although the small bowel accounts for 75% of the length and over 90% of the surface area of the gastrointestinal tract, small bowel neoplasms only account for approximately 3% of gastrointestinal cancers. Which of the following is not a possible protective mechanism in the small bowel that accounts for the relatively low rate of adenocarcinoma in the small bowel compared to the colon?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Higher concentration of microsomal enzymes in small bowel epithelia

 

Aerophilic gram-positive bacteria transform bile salts into deoxycholic acid, a tumor promoter. Overall, the small bowel has a much lower concentration of these bacteria than the colon. The ileum has the highest density of these organisms when compared to the duodenum and the jejunum. Thus far, the role of gram-negative bacteria, if any, in the pathogenesis of small bowel neoplasms is unknown. Microsomal enzymes, including benzopyrene hydroxylase, in the small bowel epithelia are thought to neutralize food-derived carcinogens and protect the small bowel from the development of cancer. Finally, the shorter transit time through the small bowel (compared to the large bowel) is thought to minimize contact time between the small bowel and potential carcinogens.

questions.text: A 23-year-old man with HL was treated successfully with the ABVD regimen. Which of the following drugs used in the treatment of this patient is cell cycle specific?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Plant alkaloids

 

Although all the drugs mentioned in the options (except alkylating agents) are cell cycle specific – the treatment regime is ABVD. In the regime Bleomycin (antitumor antibiotic – G2 specific) and Vinblastine (vinca alkaloid- M specific) are cell cycle specific drugs. Adriamycin (antitumor antibiotic) and Dacarbazine (alkylating agent) is not cell cycle specific.

 

In the options Corticosteroids (G1 specific) and antimetabolites (S specific) are cell cycle specific drugs but they are not a part of ABVD regime
